title: Markets Mixed As Traders Await US Data, Fed Speakers

content.background: Asian markets were mixed following a tepid performance on Wall Street, with profit-taking tempering hopes for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts next year. Traders are awaiting key US inflation data due later this week.
content.summary: A string of indicators pointing to a slowing economy and below-forecast rise in consumer prices have fueled optimism that the US central bank has hiked borrowing costs for the last time this cycle. However, there is concern that the readings could point to weakness down the line. Central bank officials are expected to stick to their line that policy decisions will be based on data. Expectations of rate cuts have put pressure on the dollar. Traders are also watching developments in oil markets as OPEC and its key allies gear up for a meeting.

title: Record-Breaking Spending on US Cyber Monday

content.background: Spending on Cyber Monday in the US is projected to exceed $12 billion, a record high. Bargain hunters are taking advantage of deals on various items, including toys, electronics, and clothing. Retailers have been using push notifications, text messages, and video streaming ads to entice shoppers. Online spending reached $8.3 billion by 6 pm EST, and a significant portion of spending is expected between 6 pm and 11 pm EST. The use of buy now, pay later services is expected to alleviate financial stress for holiday shoppers. Some experts are cautious about consumer strength due to higher interest rates and depleted savings.
content.summary: US shoppers are set to spend over $12 billion on Cyber Monday, with a significant portion spent during the last few hours. Retailers have been successful in attracting shoppers with discounts and promotions. The use of buy now, pay later services is expected to relieve financial strain. However, caution is raised regarding consumer strength due to higher interest rates and decreasing savings levels.

title: BofA Forecasts 10% Rise in S&P 500 by 2024

content.background: BofA Global Research predicts that the S&P 500 will climb by 10% by the end of 2024, citing the large-cap companies' ability to adapt to higher interest rates compared to smaller ones.
content.summary: U.S. stocks are expected to continue their upward trajectory, with BofA projecting a 10% increase in the S&P 500 by the end of 2024. BofA believes that larger companies in the index are better positioned to handle higher interest rates than smaller companies. This forecast is in contrast to concerns about small-cap stocks struggling in a higher rate environment.
